paragraphs.text: CIA Report, Funding the Government: How can Obama, Congress defy the Constitution?
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: When the government is waving at us with its right hand, so to speak, it is the government's left hand that we should be watching
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Just as a magician draws your attention to what he wants you to see so
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: you will not observe how his trick is performed
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: last week presented a textbook example of public disputes masking hidden deceptions
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Here is what happened
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: Last week was dominated by two huge news stories
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: One was the revelation by the Senate Intelligence Committee of torture committed by CIA agents and contractors on 119 detainees in the post-9/11 era -- 26 of whom were tortured for months by mistake
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In that revelation of anguish and error were the conclusions by CIA agents themselves that their torture had not produced helpful information
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: President Obama acknowledged that the CIA had tortured
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: yet
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: he directed the Department of Justice not to prosecute those who tortured and those who authorized it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The other substantial news story was the compromise achieved by Congress and the White House to fund the government through the end of September 2015
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That legislation, which is 2,000 pages in length, was not read by anyone who voted for it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It spends a few hundred billion dollars more than the government will collect in tax revenue
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: The compromise was achieved through bribery
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: members of Congress bought and sold votes by adding goodies (in the form of local expenditures of money borrowed by the federal government) to the bill that were never debated or independently voted upon and were added solely to achieve the votes needed for passage
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This is how the federal government operates today
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Both parties participate in it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They have turned the public treasury into a public trough
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Hidden in the law that authorized the government to spend more than it will collect was a part about funding for the 16 federal civilian intelligence agencies
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: hidden in that was a clause, inserted by the same Senate Intelligence Committee that revealed the CIA torture, authorizing the National Security Agency to gather and retain nonpublic data for five years and to share it with law enforcement and with foreign governments
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "Nonpublic data" is the government's language referring to the content of the emails, text messages, telephone calls, bank statements, utility bills and credit card bills of nearly every innocent person in America -- including members of Congress, federal judges, public officials and law enforcement officials
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I say "innocent" because the language of this legislation -- which purports to make lawful the NSA spying we now all know about-- makes clear that those who spy upon us needn't have any articulable suspicion or probable cause for spying
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The need for articulable suspicion and probable cause has its origins in the Fourth Amendment to the Constitution
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which was written to prohibit what Congress just authorized
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That amendment was a reaction to the brutish British practice of rummaging through the homes of American colonists, looking for anything that might be illegal
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It is also a codification of our natural right to privacy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It requires that if the government wants nonpublic data from our persons, houses, papers or effects, it must first present evidence of probable cause to a judge and then ask the judge for a search warrant
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Probable cause is a level of evidence that is sufficient to induce a judge into concluding that it is more likely than not that the place to be examined contains evidence of crimes
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In order to seek probable cause, the government must first have an articulable suspicion about the person or place it has targeted
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: Were this not in the law, then nothing would stop the government from fishing expeditions in pursuit of anyone it wants to pursue
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And fishing expeditions turn the presumption of liberty on its head
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The presumption of liberty is based on the belief that our rights are natural to us
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: that we may exercise them without a permission slip from the government and without its surveillance
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Until last week, that is
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Last week, Congress, by authorizing the massive NSA spying to continue and by authorizing the spies to share what they have seized with law enforcement, basically permitted the fishing expeditions that the Fourth Amendment was written to prevent
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: How can the president and Congress defy the Constitution, you might ask?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Hasn't every member of the government taken an oath to uphold the Constitution?
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: Doesn't the Constitution create the presidency and the Congress?
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: How can politicians purport to change it?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The answers to these questions are obvious, as is the belief of most of those in government that they can write any law and regulate any behavior and ignore the Constitution they have sworn to uphold whenever they want
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: so long as they can get away with it
paragraphs.label: assumption
